title: Learn to Ride Better with Jamie Robinson -- /RideApart

comments.text: Those glasses make it look like she's got a unibrow.﻿
comments.author: The Bro Era

comments.text:
Hey Jamie! Remember when you were a privateer 250cc "g.p." rider for many 
years and had a column in Fastbikes or Performance Bikes,or some crap? I 
remember you were always complaining,like all Pommies at the time,that you 
weren't winning because you,"didn't have a Factory Bike". Well,somehow,you 
were given a Factory Bike for the G.P.'s and did nothing on it.I also 
remember reading your column that year,1997,and you were saying the 
bike,a Factory Suzuki rgv250,was just way too slow compared to the 
other Factory Bikes.Well,at the final round,your team mate couldn't ride,so 
a local rider was procured by the team.Barry Sheene suggested a local 
superbike rider,Troy Bayliss.This guy had not ridden a racebike for several 
months,and had NEVER ridden a 250 GP bike.But without any testing on it, he 
almost put it on pole,led the race several times,and just missed a podium 
finish.He ran with top five guys throughout the whole race,leading onto the 
straight many times,only to be blown past on the straight,but then riding 
around the outside of them of the fast corners,much to the surprise of the 
World Championships top four riders'.I remember you crashed in that 
race,again,while running mid-pack.I remember Troy being interviewed after 
the race and saying happily,"It's a great little bike!" The lesson here is 
never blame the machinery for your lack of ability.That performance by Troy 
Bayliss at Phillip Island would have been very embarrassing for you. ﻿

comments.author: left lefty

comments.text:
here we learn to brake with al 5 fingers end NOT 2. You start braking with 
the pink finger and end with point finger. Braking will be safer because 
the pink is less strong. De midle and pointing finger are strong and 
braking can be to agressive. Starting with the pink is less agressive and 
braking force can be build up.﻿
comments.author: kookworst

comments.text:
It also gives you the ability to trail brake to the apex (still braking 
while going to the turn and slowly releasing said brake), but this is a 
racing skill I wouldn't suggest to anyone with out the ablity or on the 
street unless you are in the twist & you KNOW you are entering the turn hot 
as hell. Then trail brake, if you feel the bike start to fall pick it back 
up with the throttle.
comments.author: Vox McMuffen

The idea of using 2 fingers is so you are still able to brake while 
rev-matching on the downshift.

comments.author: Floyd Burdett

comments.text:
Well from some of the videos I've seen, like Twist of the Wrist 2 by Kieth 
Code (you can find the video on youtube) they seem to suggest being on the 
gas (lightly) on corner entry almost before you even start to lean to keep 
the suspension loaded so you don't have that light sort of floating 
sensation from the suspension.

Now if you watch the onboard cameras from actual racing such as the motogp 
riders showing both acceleration percentage as well as braking percentage 
in little bar graphs you'll find that the racers are hard on the brakes all 
the way into the corner almost to apex and then release brakes and coast 
for a very short while and then roll on the gas as they get to or are 
passing through corner apex.

It would seem to me that the motogp riders know what they're doing, but if 
you notice, the timing of when they're off both the brake and throttle 
(coasting) seems to correlate with just before apex or so.

Looking at how they actually are going into the corners, hard under 
braking, they are both sliding the bike into and out of the corners.  
Looking at the profile the bike traverses through the corner, I think it 
would not necessarily be a round arc like that of a circle, but more of a 
parabolic or hyperbolic shape like a parabola with the tip or point of the 
parabola corresponding with the apex of the corner.

Similar to auto racing, they are sliding the rear of the bike into the 
corner so that they can swing the nose around to point towards the corner 
exit before they apply the gas. ( helping to turn the bike faster than if 
the tires were not sliding)

If you think about it, the point at which they're both off the brakes and 
before they apply throttle is the point in the corner at which their speed 
is lowest (this could correspond with the tip of the parabola or 
hyperbola).  This would make sense as if the bike were to be slightly 
unstable, having it unstable (or unloaded) at the slowest point in the 
corner sounds the safest/fastest.

If you were to slide the bike to point the nose towards the exit, the ideal 
time would be at this point of lowest speed.  So infact it would appear 
that as you are on the brakes up until the sharpest point, then at the 
lowest speed and sharpest point of the curve you give it a little more 
brake than before to allow the rear of the bike to slide the most to "come 
around" the tip of the parabola and point the nose towards the exit.

This would correspond with the ideal timing to release the brakes and be 
off the gas as it would be a momentary excess input of the brakes to get 
the rear end to come around the most.  During this time you would ideally 
be off the brakes and gas and as the rear end begins to slow from this 
slide, you would start to roll on the gas.

Performing this action at this point in time would load the rear of the 
bike, transferring traction to the rear and allowing the rear tire more 
grip.  Then after the tire has "hooked up" or gained traction you begin to 
roll on the gas more as at this point you are both pointed towards the 
corner exit as well as have regained traction and control via the throttle.

All of this however depends on the geometry of the corner itself, and what 
comes after the particular corner.  For instance a very sharp corner with a 
short straight afterward could see a very exaggerated or "sharp" looking 
parabola/hyperbola.

A long sweeper with a long straight afterward would see a much wider or 
"smoother" version of this.

And there are probably an infinite number of variations in-between.
comments.author: spitfirezip100

comments.text:
Thanks or your input!
I will be going to a Track event Saturday, but it will not be a true "Track 
Day" where I can work individually on 'challenges'. But I will also be 
going from the track to twisty mountain roads, and will work more on my 
cornering skills. 
The things you mentioned are the same that I do with driving a car at top 
performance...but I can't seem to get the same 'timing' right on my bike. I 
can't "heel and toe" on my bike, the way I can on my cars...where I can 
still maintain a slight "overlap" of the application of acceleration as I 
release the braking forces...so there is not a 'snatch' in the chain as 
power is applied.
Again, Thanks for your response! I hope you have a GREAT weekend of riding!
comments.author: Floyd Burdett

comments.text:
I'm not an expert but it just comes down to judging the speed of the 
corner, if you go out to the track try braking later. To begin with work 
out what speed you are comfortable with taking on the corner as you go 
around the track try braking a little later each time.

You may get to the point where the bike's front wheel locks up, if this is 
happening you perhaps should do a few more laps and allow the tires to warm 
up, or drop the pressure by a few psi. It does also come down to what tires 
you are using, if you are using a touring tire you should be mindful that 
it won't gain much extra grip as it isn't designed for grip but more 
longevity.

You also need to be mindful how much brake pressure you apply at the 
current lean angle as the front is already loaded with cornering forces, 
braking too hard may cause you to lose the front.

It may not only be braking, but getting back on the gas earlier can help 
too. Basically get back on the gas as soon as possible when you've reached 
a point where you feel it is safe for you to do so, don't overstep your 
confidence with this by throttling too hard as you may lose your rear. 

I haven't really explained it too well, I've got a few videos showing my 
braking into corners and accelerating out of them. I can however suggest 
what everyone suggests and that is watching Twist of the Wrist 2, it makes 
clear the fundamentals on how to ride and what you should and shouldn't do.

by many as the cornering bible. Reading, studying and putting into practice 
the techinues it teaches has worked for me.

learn on an old bad ass looking POS. Now I have more experience with modern 
bikes/technology and I'm never looking back.
comments.author: HellooMarie

comments.text:
I think its not so much dust but just old tar that's kinda ripped up. I 
paid attention after reading your comment and saw some close ups that 
didn't really look to bad, but from some of those shots it does look really 
bad.
comments.author: xMisterTryHard

comments.text:
What's your definition of a new rider? Because before last year when I 
bought my CBR600F4i I had never ridden on the street but had ridden dirt 
bikes. I haven't had a problem though, I just took it easy the first two to 
three weeks and got used to the bike/power.
comments.author: xMisterTryHard

comments.text:
Riding a bike is impossible without implementing counter steering whether 
you know what it is or not. Not even worth mentioning. I learned on dirt 
bikes and no one ever told me what it was. If you AREN'T crashing, you ARE 
counter-steering.
comments.author: ams914

comments.text:
Stick with 1 or 2 cylinders. Anything with 4 will have a power band that's 
guaranteed to send a new rider into the guard rail.
comments.author: xXTommyCXx
